title: How to Remove Vomit Stains from Clothing

steps.title: Scrape any solids off the garment.
steps.content: Scrape any solids off the garment. As with any stain, the faster you move to treat the stain, the more success you will have removing it. This may be particularly difficult with vomit, since handling clothing covered with vomit is not very appealing, but it's in your best interest to work quickly. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the stain with warm water.
steps.content: Rinse the stain with warm water. If treated immediately, a strong blast of water may be enough to get the vomit out of your clothes. Organic stains can sometimes be removed with a little water and agitation.

steps.title: Soak the garment in a bucket of water if you can't treat it right away.
steps.content: Soak the garment in a bucket of water if you can't treat it right away. Because the stain will be far more difficult to remove if it is allowed to dry and set, immersing the soiled clothing in water will prevent the stain from drying.

steps.title: Dampen the stain with warm water and cover it with baking soda.
steps.content: Dampen the stain with warm water and cover it with baking soda. [2] X Research source Apply a generous layer, enough to cover the stain to about 1/4 inch (1/2 cm) thick. The baking soda will absorb the smell and also help lift the stain from the fibers.

steps.title: Pour lemon juice or vinegar over the stain.
steps.content: Pour lemon juice or vinegar over the stain. The baking soda will begin to fizz. Rub the stain with your fingers or a toothbrush. Try to rub out as much of the stain as possible. Rinse the baking soda/lemon juice mixture from the clothing with warm water.

steps.title: Squirt dish detergent on the stain and allow it to soak in a container of water.
steps.content: Squirt dish detergent on the stain and allow it to soak in a container of water. Before soaking, agitate the detergent by rubbing it with your fingers, scrubbing it with a toothbrush, or rubbing the fabric against itself. [3] X Research source Allow the garment to soak for at least an hour, maybe more if the stain is very stubborn. Rinse the clothing with warm water after soaking. Treat the stain with dishwashing liquid once more, then wash as normal.

steps.title: Pretreat the stain.
steps.content: Pretreat the stain. Use your preferred brand of pre-spot treatment, saturating the stain on the front and the back of the fabric. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wash the garment in the hottest water recommended.
steps.content: Wash the garment in the hottest water recommended. Different types of fabric can handle different temperatures at water. Check the label on your clothing to see if it can be washed in warm or hot water. Use a detergent that is formulated to remove stains. If the stain still remains, repeat the process.

steps.title: Soak the stain in a mixture of 1 qt warm water, 1/2 TSP detergent, and 1 TBSP ammonia.
steps.content: Soak the stain in a mixture of 1 qt warm water, 1/2 TSP detergent, and 1 TBSP ammonia. Use a soft brush or your nails to lightly scrape and agitate the stain. [5] X Research source Use a liquid detergent if possible. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse with water and launder as usual.
steps.content: Rinse with water and launder as usual. It is important you remove all traces of the ammonia. Rinse thoroughly and wring the garment to make sure it is completely washed out. [7] X Research source
